Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: Kafka.

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: The keeper of the files is still waiting for your final summation of the Erlanger claim.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I gave it to him yesterday.

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: You didn't give it to me.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No, I left it in his office.

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: Did you see him?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I've never seen him.  I don't believe there is a keeper of the files.

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: He's usually in the storage room sorting things out.  He can't close the file on a case until he has the concluding report.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: He has it, he just hasn't noticed it yet, all right?

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: Who's to say he ever will?  He's a timid old man and quite careful not to tread on anyone's toes -- In fact, I'm the only one he trusts and he wouldn't even look at a document if it didn't first come through me.

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: In an organization as efficient as ours, if a document once in a great while gets lost it might never be found at all.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Burgel, I thought it would be easier, as long as I was passing --

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: But I'm the messenger.  An error like this damages my credibility.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Your credibility -- yes, it's well known.

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: When I deliver a message the very act of delivering it, you might say, gives it an official stamp, and only in this way are both the sender and the receiver satisfied that it was delivered at all.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I'll commit that to memory.

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: Your position in this firm is not unassailable.

Speaker: bizarre voice
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I'm sorry to disturb you -- I wonder if you know where my friend Eduard is?

Speaker: bizarre voice
Dialogue: I can't hear you! -- You'd better come in.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- I didn't want to bother you.

Speaker: concierge
Dialogue: Well, you have.  What do you want?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: My friend Eduard, I wonder if you've seen him?  He hasn't been in to work, I thought he might be ill.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: You didn't have to get out of bed -- I could have taken the key.

Speaker: concierge
Dialogue: Yes, I'm sure you could.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Well, he's not here.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Do you think you ought to do that?

Speaker: concierge
Dialogue: The manners of a tramp!  It's my house, isn't it?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Miss Rossmann?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I'm Kafka -- I work upstairs in Accident --

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: You're a friend of Eduard Raban's.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Why would you suppose so?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Oh -- well, I thought he once mentioned --

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: One of you must be mistaken.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I'm sorry, but I just wondered --

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Excuse me, I have to copy this for

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: You're late -- I knew it would happen one day.

Speaker: margarete
Dialogue: -- This is our friend Anna who works with us on the magazine.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I've been hearing all about you.

Speaker: ernst
Dialogue: Don't worry, Kafka -- I championed your virtues.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I'd like to hear them.

Speaker: julius
Dialogue: Anna's new to the city -- we wouldn't frighten her needlessly.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I've lived all my life in this city -- it frightens me.  As it draws me closer into its web.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: -- This is an ancient lament.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No, but do you realize why? -- it has no present.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: -- I'm hoping to live in the Old Quarter.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Even the so-called New Town isn't so new.  Only the people.  People of the future living in buildings of the past.  Has anyone seen Eduard?

Speaker: margarete
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: julius
Dialogue: Oh, him.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: What d'you mean, oh him?  He's a perfectly nice person, he's never missed a day before.

Speaker: ernst
Dialogue: Perhaps he's taken up with those traveling players you two were so fond of.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No, it's me who always wanted to run away with them -- except that that life would be far too hectic for me.  I'm worried about him, no one's seen him.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: Haven't you ever called in sick and gone roaming about, free of responsibility to anyone, if only for a day?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: When you work for a medical firm you can't call in sick.  They know malingerers like a dog knows fleas.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: You work in the insurance department?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: You have been hearing the sordid side then.

Speaker: margarete
Dialogue: Be pleased -- you constantly inspire people to take an interest in your life.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I should think it's very interesting work.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: My father always said I had no ambition.

Speaker: stella
Dialogue: The cabaret will be packed this time of night -- we'll never get in.

Speaker: julius
Dialogue: Well, it has to be the cabaret because there's nowhere else to go.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Home, I think.

Speaker: julius
Dialogue: Home?

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: You know I can't stay up late.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Home is the last resort --

Speaker: ernst
Dialogue: -- Do you know Bizzlebek -- the gravedigger?

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: Stonecutter, if you please.

Speaker: margarete
Dialogue: Sculptor, if only he'd admit it.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: No one should admit being an artist unless they're paid for it.  If you go to the cabaret mention my name -- they'll find a table for you.

Speaker: ernst
Dialogue: Bizzlebek has ways and means denied lesser mortals.  It comes from working in the cemetery all day -- he's able to transcent the physical world.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: No -- it only makes me view people dispassionately as so many ... slabs.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: Quartz ... slate ... gravel ... granite ... flint ...  Marble.

Speaker: julius
Dialogue: My God, look, he's marching forward willingly to make human contact.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Hello again.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I've never seen you here before.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Have you looked?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Well -- nice to know life exists outside the office.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No, really, I have to go home too.

Speaker: margarete
Dialogue: We're keeping him from his true vocation.

Speaker: julius
Dialogue: I know, he consists of writing. We wouldn't be his friends if we didn't threaten his solitude!

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Where do you live?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Up there.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I tried finding a place on Castle Hill when I arrived.  I wanted to share the majesty.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: It's only majestic from here. When you get closer you see it for what it really is.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: What is it really?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: A glorified office block.  They keep all the old records there -- the final resting place for facts and figures that have ceased to matter in the world of the living.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Well, as long as I admire it from afar it shouldn't worry me if it's hollow.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: It's more than hollow.  It's stillborn.  For all its size it serves no purpose.  It's just there -- like death -- hovering over a breathing city.

Speaker: margarete
Dialogue: Don't worry about your friend -- I'm sure he'll turn up.

Speaker: ernst
Dialogue: What are you working on, Kafka?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I'm writing a story about a man who wakes up one morning to find himself transformed into a giant insect.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: I've read your stories.  They're fantastic.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I don't know what you could have read.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: Just what you've published.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- In magazines nobody reads.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: I read the one about the penal colony.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Did you?

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: The needles inscribing the judgement into the flesh of the man.  Very good.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: If I could sculpt as well as that, I'd be quite proud of myself.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: "As Gregor Samsa awoke one morning from disturbing dreams he ... from unsettling dreams ... uneasy dreams ... Gregor Samsa ... Gregor ...?"  Carl.  George.  Rudolf ...

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: You know him?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: ... Yes.

Speaker: first man
Dialogue: His name is Eduard Raban?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: ... Yes.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Inspector Grubach.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: Kafka -- is that your real name?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Yes.  Yes, of course -- why wouldn't it be?

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: When was the last time you saw Mr. Raban?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Wednesday.  We left the office together.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: Did you go anywhere afterwards -- to have a drink perhaps?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No, we said goodbye outside the building.  He went off, as usual, toward his house.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: Your office is the Workmen's --

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- Accident and Compensation Association.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: Where you've been employed for seven years.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Eight -- and seven months.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: Engaged in the manufacture and distribution of ... pills and so forth.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Well -- other departments are, yes.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: Would you describe your relationship with the dead man as close?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Yes.  Since he came to the office, almost three years ago, we've been quite good friends.  How was Eduard ...

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: He was found in the River.  Could he swim?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: Was he depressed?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No.  He didn't seem to be.  Do you think he drowned himself?

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: Grown men don't normally fall into the river, do they?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No, I suppose not.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: He might have had a drink or two, despite what you think.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Can I ask -- how you found me?

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: His landlady knew of no other friends to refer us to.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I don't think he really had any. He had no family either.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: We know that.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: He wasn't a lonely man, though.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: What makes you think so?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: ... Just a perception.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: I don't usually involve myself with you people in the Old Quarter -- but the River runs its own course. It won't be the last time it deposits its unwanted debris on my doorstep.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Probably not.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: Anyway, I'd like you to reflect that in me you have -- I won't say a friend, because we're complete fencers, of course -- from distinctly incompatible social classes -- but to some extent, shall we say, an interested third party.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I'll bear that in mind.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: -- Should you happen upon anything that might be relevant.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: You wanted to see me, sir.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: Sit down, Kafka.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: You've been with the firm for nearly nine years.  You've done your work diligently, there are no complaints on that score.  But there's more to the job than the work -- there are other people to consider -- and frankly, Kafka, we eel your social situation could bear improving.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: ... My ... social situation?

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: You keep too much to yourself -- you're a lone wolf.  It makes me uneasy, and if it makes me uneasy I can't imagine the impression you make on lesser employees.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: To do my work well, I have little time for --

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: You must make the time.  Where do you go off to in the lunch hour?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I usually take lunch by the River.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: It's not healthy, Kafka -- not for you and not for your workmates.  At the annual dinner this month you again failed to make an appearance.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I did not realize it was obligatory.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: Have you never wondered -- and I mention this only in passing --  why other clerks have advanced to more responsible positions while you, who have been here longer, have not?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: Attitude, Kafka.  It doesn't matter how well you do your work -- you still see it as something to be gotten on with rather than something to take an active interest in.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Well, I --

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: Oh, I know you got along with that poor fellow -- what was his name?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- Eduard --

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: -- Yes -- Raban -- but he was too much like you -- even more so perhaps.  He wasn't here as long as you, so I didn't know him as well -- but I could see the influence he was having.  I simply want you to be aware of this because you'll be happier for it.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: In any case -- don't ask me why -- the word has come down you're to be promoted.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: Your colleague's death has helped precipitate the need, though I can tell you it's been under consideration for some time.  You're to be given two assistants and a commensurate rise in salary.  That's all.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: Kafka.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: I understand you fancy yourself an author.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: In a small way.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: You might find a more athletic hobby -- put some color in your cheeks.

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: Good morning --  Or should I say good afternoon?

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Say what you like -- no one pays the least attention.

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: Oh, don't they?  I think you underestimate my station in this office and overrate your own.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Not today, Burgel.  Send one of your memos, write up one of your communiques, but for God's sake don't bother me today.

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: It's my place to offer advice, not yours -- and by advising the Chief Clerk of your unpunctuality it's certainly not my situation that's compromised, if that's what you're implying.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: You're just doing your job.

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: It's what I'm paid to do.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: You're detestable.

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: And you're late!

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: My assistants, I presume.

Speaker: assistants
Dialogue: Yes -- that's us.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I'm Kafka.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: Ludwig.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: Oskar.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: You look like brothers.

Speaker: assistants
Dialogue: Yes -- we do.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Have you worked here long?

Speaker: assistants
Dialogue: No, no, no -- quite a long time, yes.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Well, we'd better move things from my old desk.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Eduard and I had lunch together one day ... and you saw us.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: On the Embankment.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: I was having an affair with Eduard.  He didn't tell you?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: He would have.  You were his best friend.  A better friend than me.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I suspected that he -- well.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: That he was -- satisfied in that regard.  I didn't want to pry.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: It's not that we wanted to deceive anyone -- but you know how these things are looked upon at the office.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: What's funny?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: This morning it was suggested to me that my own sense of office fellowship could bear improving.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: As long as it's on their terms. If your work and your private life don't correspond to their specifications you're labelled a dangerous agitator -- with no recourse whatsoever.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: How long were you and Eduard --

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Two or three months, that's all.  -- I seduced him.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: You know as well as I do that he didn't commit suicide.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No, I don't.  I'm amazed that anyone is able to bear life with any assurance at all.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Eduard didn't see it as something that needed bearing.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: The police would know the difference, wouldn't they?

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Do you think people in the New Town care what happens over here?  This will always be the ghetto.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: He wasn't robbed.  He was identified by his wallet.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: And you believe everything the authorities tell you.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: When I have no reason to doubt.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: The very fact that they're authorities should give you reason. People will do anything to protect their own interests.  For all you know he was killed at the hands of the police.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- What could he have done to warrant that?

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Are you free tonight?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Tonight?

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: There are some people I'd like you to meet.  Can you come to the Musil district at eight o'clock?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: ... All right.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: You almost married recently, didn't you?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Last year.  I -- it was broken off.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Eduard wanted to marry me.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: And you ...?

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: I'm suspicious of men who want to marry.  I believe they think it's the only thing that will make them equal to their fathers.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- I don't know the Musil district.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: You won't have any trouble finding it.

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: We'll save the introductions.  We don't know yet if you're friend or foe.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Strangers make better foes than friends.  Will you tell me who you are altogether, if not individually?

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: Heralds of a new age -- does that sound immodest?

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: You could say we represent the unofficial view of a well-ordered society.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Ah -- we're back to the "authorities" you spoke of.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: They're ubiquitous.  What we try to do ... is make them a little less so.

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: Quite a disturbance tonight, yes? And perhaps you recall last month -- the explosion at the Municipal Courthouse that sent one of the examining magistrates to join the heavenly choir.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: ... Was Eduard one of you?

Speaker: youthful anarchist
Dialogue: The last to join us, the first to leave us.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: ... Why take me into your confidence?

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: That's obvious, isn't it?  We have an opening for a new member.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: I nominated you as a possible candidate.  You were Eduard's good friend.  He read me some of your work.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I've hardly published enough for anyone to draw conclusions from.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: You strike me as a man with a defined notion of injustice -- a high concern for the lot of your fellow men.  And yet you're able to remain an outsider.  With the concomitant air of ... superiority?

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: In short, a higher man.  It's what we want.  It's what we need.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: The distance to my fellow man is for me quite a journey.  As for being an outsider, it's never been a matter of choice.

Speaker: youthful anarchist
Dialogue: -- They may have instituted proceedings against you.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: What proceedings?

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: Preliminary investigations may already be underway.

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: You were his friend.  One link is all they need.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: The day he died, Eduard was called up to the Castle.  Did you know that?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: What of it?

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: He was summoned to help correct a minor discrepancy of some sort in the Medical Records Division. Apparently one of his claims was relevant.

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: -- Merely in the interests of order, you understand.  The officials at the Castle like to cover their tracks.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: He was never seen alive again.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: And you still maintain -- what? That he was murdered.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: He was murdered.

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: As you can imagine, a pass into the Castle -- hardly ever granted -- was an opportunity we couldn't ignore.

Speaker: youthful anarchist
Dialogue: The Castle represents every anachronism that needs to be destroyed if progress is to be made.

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: As you know, it's not the most accessible location.  Far from being depressed, Eduard was particularly excited when he brought us the news of this chance invitation. He set off that evening carrying one of our custom-made briefcases instead of his own.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: You're shocked at the thought of Eduard tossing a bomb through a window.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I have no right to be, I know.  My experience with real life  is practically nil.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: When you only see someone sitting at a desk all day, it's liable to create a false impression.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: People must think the same of me -- a quiet, dependable person.

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: You don't have to accept everything as true, my friend.  You need only accept it as necessary.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: As the bomb never went off, we can only assume he was caught with it -- and summarily executed.

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: -- Merely in the interests of order.

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: The formality of a trial would be too costly for them.  They're beginning to understand that it's the ensuing news of our actions that incites support.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Propaganda of the dead?

Speaker: youthful anarchist
Dialogue: The Castle will deny he was there any longer than his business required. They're just file clerks up there.  No doubt he was handed over to the police with the utmost discretion.

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: In any event, we've felt no repercussions as yet.  Eduard must not have talked.  You're the one they contacted.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: So that's who my foes are -- policemen and file clerks.  Law and order, you might say.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: You think what we're doing is so wrong?  And what are you doing? Pursuing goodness?  For what?  To answer to some supreme tribunal?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: My only concern is the human tribunal.  Isn't it yours?

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Yes -- which is why "quiet, dependable people" have to take charge of their own lives.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: At the cost of others?  You accuse people of murder without trial -- apparently without irony.  Did you go to the Castle with Eduard?  Then you have no idea what really might have happened that night at all -- even before or after he got there.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Your human tribunal will betray you.  Just as its members will be betrayed when they find no supreme one

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Join us, Kafka.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: It's sheer folly for anyone to try to pull through alone.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: How was your evening?

Speaker: assistants
Dialogue: Fine -- terrible.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: What was the matter with it?

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: He can't sit still.  Just when we arrive at a nightclub he wants to go to another one.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: You look tired.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: Gabriela Rossman was here looking for you.  Do you know her?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Do you?

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: We saw her naked once -- didn't we.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: Women are all you have on your mind!

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: She went to the roof to sunbathe one lunch hour -- we watched her changing.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I didn't realize you'd been here that long.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: You mean because it's been a while since there was a sunny day?  What a good detective you are.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: They keep switching us from department to department.  He doesn't mind because he can't sit still.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: We used to be in the supply section, carrying boxes of medicine about but we dropped too many of them.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: It's not too bad working here.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: You don't think it's a horrible double life from which there is probably no escape but insanity?

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I'm glad for you.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: You should be content, you know!

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: Are you looking for Gabriela Rossmann?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: I'm collecting Eduard's things. If there's anything you want, take it or I'll give it to charity.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Burgel gave me this -- what does it mean?

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Burgel! -- I didn't leave it with him.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Why were you given notice?

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: They're not obliged to tell.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: It couldn't be for that incident with Burgel the other day.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Of course it could -- Burgel's been trying to get me thrown out as long as I can remember.  He could've killed Eduard.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: You don't believe that.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: I wouldn't put it past him.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: It seems I knew Eduard a little bit, after all.

Speaker: concierge
Dialogue: Lodgers!  Not one of them thinks to spare me such spectacles!

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: You might think -- I thought so myself at first -- that Burgel's too insignificant to be dangerous. But that's the very reason to beware! It's the small men to watch out for -- the ones who substitute method for character.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Now you've fallen into his trap. When he goes to bed at night Burgel dreams of inspiring as much fear in others as they inspire in him.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: It's still easier for you to understand suicide, isn't it.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: That street down there -- I always used to call it the approach road for suicides.  It leads straight down to the bridge and the River.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Burgel hated Eduard.  And me.  I'm sure he knew about us -- and I'm sure it drove him mad.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Burgel doesn't like anybody!

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: He used to like me -- very much more than I liked him.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: He's jealous, yes, but that jealous?  He's too cautious.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Of course he is -- the Castle precincts are not the safest part of the city after dark.  People disappear up there regularly.   If you want to lie in wait for someone, that's the place to do it.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Now you're saying Eduard was lured there?

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: How often does one of our clerks have business in the house of records?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I've heard of it happening.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: And Burgel is the bringer of messages, isn't he?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Usually.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Or what if there really was an error? -- I don't know what kind -- any kind that needed correcting -- and what if Burgel was responsible for it?  One mistake -- even a small one in a firm like ours -- it could cost him a promotion.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: First these nameless authorities were the root of all evil, now it's insignificant Burgel.  If indeed there was a mistake -- and a minor one at that -- you're suggesting someone went to a lot of trouble over something so trivial as to not matter at all.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: What seems important to these people is not determined by the amount of work it entails -- you're far from understanding the authorities if you believe that.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Now Burgel's one of the authorities?

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: For all his big talk he is.  Does he really have access to the Directors of the firm as he always claims?  -- or only the Deputy Managers -- people of no importance whatsoever.  Someone ought to follow him for a change.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: You won't make any sense of it while you're upset.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Burgel is only there for one purpose -- to spy on the employees and report any and all indiscretions, real or imagined.  If he didn't send Eduard to the Castle, you can be damn sure he's in league with whoever greeted him there.  All those bastards are in league with each other -- why can't you see that!

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: ... I don't see anything.  I see a message on its way to me -- with all the right answers.  Only it never arrives -- it's always just on its way.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Eduard ...

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Your ignorance of the way things are here is so appalling that it makes my head spin to listen to you and compare what you say and have in mind with the real situation!

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: You said she was extremely upset. People who are extremely upset -- Kafka -- are given to disappearing in a hurry.  They go and calm down for a day or so and then they come back.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: But that's just my point -- she was more than upset, she was livid. She slammed every door on her way downstairs -- except that one.  I was just behind her and I didn't even hear that one shut -- not at all.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: That's not what I call conclusive evidence of an abduction.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: If someone was waiting here in the hallway to spirit her away, wouldn't they have shut the door as quietly as possible?

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: Why would someone want to kidnap this woman -- the name is Rossmann?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: You told me to contact you if anything relevant came up -- Gabriela is relevant.  When I spoke to you before I didn't know she'd been seeing Eduard.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: That's been noted.  But where does it lead us?  Unless you have something more to add.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: She's missing.  I went to her house and she hadn't returned there.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: She lost her job today.  Just between you and me, I'd probably go away and brood a bit myself.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Maybe it's true then what she said.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: What did she say?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: That the police may have allegiance to something other than truth.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- She didn't think Eduard committed suicide.  She was convinced of it.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: I'm going to say something, and I hope it's quite clear because I won't be repeating it.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: We don't have to hunt for criminals. We're drawn towards them.  The guilty show us the way.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: Where are your friends?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Good question.  Who are my friends ... would also be of interest.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Gabriela was right -- it's easier for me to understand suicide. I'm a practicing suicide.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: -- In what sense?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Bachelorhood is just the slow form.  The bachelor doesn't sew seeds.  Only the moment matters. The space he occupies grows smaller and smaller -- until the only space right for him is his coffin.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: These strange stories you write -- they come naturally, do they?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Naturally? -- that's not the word I would have chosen.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: Let's go to a brothel then, Kafka, come on.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I haven't got the energy.  I mean, I have to conserve my energy.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: Why do you work in that hideous insurance office?  -- dealing with people who fall off ladders.  Now take me -- I make my living as a stone mason.  It's not my art -- but it's the tools of my art.  You could be -- a journalist.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: That would be even worse -- it would be a compromise.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: Success or nothing?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No -- not even success.  My writing is not for making a living -- it's for living.  Not for other people, it's for me.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: ... I'm the exile.  Gabriela was right about that too.

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: We have another theory.

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: We may have attached too little importance to the reason Eduard was summoned to the Castle to begin with.

Speaker: youthful anarchist
Dialogue: -- To correct a small discrepancy, you may recall.

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: -- Ah, but what if it wasn't?

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: -- Small.

Speaker: youthful anarchist
Dialogue: -- What if it was a large discrepancy?

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: Yours is a very powerful and important firm -- it has a lot at stake.

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: Perhaps Eduard was closer than he knew to discovering it and so had to be silenced.

Speaker: youthful anarchist
Dialogue: -- Or he was even more an innocent victim than that -- he was chosen to bear the blame if the crime was uncovered by anyone else.

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: -- The crime so scandalous that the poor young clerk committed suicide rather than own up to it.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: That's mad.

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: -- Oh, yes, it's mad.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- You said so yourself the firm is large and powerful.  If the discrepancy really was something big, Eduard's responsibility would still have to be small.  No poor young clerk could find himself in such a fix.

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: When a scapegoat is needed, my friend ...

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: We have to know what he was working on at the time of his death.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: He worked on routine claims.  His visit to the Castle was probably as minor a mission as he said it was.

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: Why are you so aggressively unimaginative?  Eduard is no longer the only casualty.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Then why haven't I been --

Speaker: youthful anarchist
Dialogue: -- Kidnapped or murdered?  Because your connection with Eduard was obvious and above board -- not as easily misconstrued.

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: -- Not secretive, therefore not suspicious.

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: -- Gabriela, on the other hand, had made an enemy of this man Burgel.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Oh, Burgel!  Gabriela was having an affair with Eduard.  They were both members of this group.  If any crime's been discovered and people are paying for it, I'd look to yourselves!

Speaker: pockmarked anarchist
Dialogue: The loyal civil servant.  I suppose you'll deny that shortchanging the workers to whom compensation is due is standard company policy.

Speaker: bearded anarchist
Dialogue: It wouldn't surprise us if the discrepancy was between medicines sent and medicines received.

Speaker: youthful anarchist
Dialogue: -- People die for such discrepancies.

Speaker: solemn anarchist
Dialogue: We must have a look at Eduard's file.

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: "Raban" -- that'll be nearly at the back of the alphabet.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: It usually is.

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: I'm not obliged to give you access, you know -- not without authorization -- but I'll make an exception this one time.

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: "Raban" did you say?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Yes.  Isn't it there?

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: Wait a minute.  "Raban?"  Where have I heard that name?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: He's the clerk who died last week. From the insurance department

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: Why would we keep files on dead employees?  All old files are sent up to the Castle.  Do you think we have room for two hundred years worth personnel records?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: It's gone out so quickly?

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: Whenever an employee departs, shall we say, it's up to the head of his department to requisition his file, reassign any outstanding claims, and send it off.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- You mean my Chief has it.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Excuse me, sir -- I understand you have Eduard Raban's file.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I wonder if I might look to see if there's an address for family -- I thought I'd like to write to them.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: No -- just as I thought -- no entry for family.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: Was there something else?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No -- I just -- I feel a sense of obligation.  He was my friend -- if I can be of any help -- closing his affairs.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: No, there's only one report to complete.  I'll be doing it myself and submitting it to the Castle today or tomorrow.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I see -- it's just the Erlanger claim then.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: The Orlac claim.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Sorry, yes -- well -- thank you, sir.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: Kafka.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: You're too sensitive.  Let your friend rest in peace.  I've known suicides.  Such a song- and-dance about nothing.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: chief clerk
Dialogue: Give it up.

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: If it was Accounts you wanted why did you ask for Employees?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Orlac is an account?

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: It's a factory in the northern mountains.  One of our best customers.  Without a proper request I'm not obliged to do this, you understand -- but I'll make an exception on this one occasion.

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: At least the account is current even if the employee isn't.

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: That place has so many accidents, it's a good thing the type of peasants who live up there don't seem to have any trouble propagating their race.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: All these in the last year?

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: You must have read about it in the papers -- there was a terrible cave-in.  It wouldn't have been so bad, but even the Medical Officer for the district was killed!

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I did read that.  They gave him a posthumous medal.

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: Dr. Murnau was the bravest of men. He spent an entire career in those backwaters with no regard for personal gain.  A great loss.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: This is the cross-reference of clerks who've worked on Orlac claims?

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: Your Chief will send me the final summation when he's finished with it.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Once a file's been sent to the Caste, is it possible to recall it for review?

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: Of course not.  Only by a Director of the firm.  Who'd want to let in all kinds of riff-raff off the streets?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: What good are records if they're not open for public inspection?

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: These laws have been with us for centuries -- how can you doubt them?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: What if I petitioned one of the Directors?

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: You do not summon them -- they summon you -- and this, of course, hardly ever happens, if at all. The Directors are an eccentric lot and by nature cautious.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Where do our records go to in the Castle?

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: We're a medical firm, aren't we? They go to the Medical Records Section.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I could always apply there.

Speaker: keeper
Dialogue: It so happens, my dear simple sir, that the Head of Medical Records at the Castle is one of the Directors of this firm.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Do you mind!

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: -- I was just trying to finish some work!

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: You mean you've actually begun some?

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: -- Just because he's done nothing today, he doesn't want me to show him up!

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: My assistants!  You might as well have fallen from the sky for all the thought that was spent in choosing you!

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: It's not our fault.  We're naturally nervous.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: And we're upset too.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: What's the matter with you?

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: I can't make a simple statement without him taking issue with it

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- You should meet my father.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: We've been together too long.  His personality is overflowing into mine and vice versa.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: -- How would you like to be in a horrible situation like that?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: All right, you might as well go home -- go on.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Well, what're you waiting for?

Speaker: kafka's voice
Dialogue: "-- oh, and thank you for the suit from Father, although I don't know why he didn't simply return it.  If it's too small for him why do you immediately suppose it will fit me? ... Your son ... Your loving son ... Your somewhat loving son ... Your occasionally loving son ... Your incapable-of-loving son ... Your absolutely-bored-to-death-with-any- kind-of-family-life son ..."

Speaker: burgel
Dialogue: The Chief Clerk would like this ready for tomorrow morning.  He says it should only take you an extra hour or two.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- Help!  HELP!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Did you think you'd be safe back in your little burrow?

Speaker: other voice
Dialogue: No matter how deep a hole you dig for yourself, the beast will always find you.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: We're to take you to the Castle.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: So.  You're the guides up there. And we thought it was Burgel.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: They wouldn't let Burgel into the Castle.  You should look upon this as a great favor.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I don't want any favors from the Castle -- just my rights.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: We answer directly to Ekman, the Senior Partner -- he practically runs the Castle.  In a case like this you're better off dealing with the highest authority -- even though it's equally futile.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: When you speak to him you have to lean quite near his right ear because the left doesn't work so well.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: For all your incompetence I was beginning to think you were at least loyal to me.  You're very good ham actors.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: -- Just doing our job.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: It's a farce.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: We think you'd better accept your position instead of pointlessly annoying us.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: What position?  Being prosecuted in a case like this means having already lost it.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: Still, we're probably closer to you at the moment than any of your fellow human beings.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Close only by virtue of antithesis.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: My assistants.  I should have known. Nothing is given to me.  I have to acquire everything.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: It's all right to be sarcastic in private to us -- because we have a sense of humor -- but when we're up at the Castle we suggest you don't make a fuss.  It would spoil the not unfavorable impression you make in other respects.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: Frankly, we don't understand why you've even bothered pursuing this business.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: It would be more accurate to say that it has pursued me.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: But your goal is so hard to reach. Do you think the official network would surrender to one man?  We would never think of attempting anything remotely as difficult.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: My mother used to tell us of the young man who decided to ride to the next village and how she was afraid that -- not even mentioning accidents -- the span of a normal happy life might fall far short of the time needed for such a trip.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: You've dropped some money.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: You work in the cemetery.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: A man must eat --  And drink.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: The Castle cemetery.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: Are you sure you wouldn't prefer going through official channels?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Official channels -- a lot of good they've done me.  My only hope is to approach the officials personally.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: -- I'm flattered, of course, to be considered a friend -- even without knowing all the details.  -- To see such determination is reward enough for me.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: The Kafka men are famous for it, you know.  Delivering meat barefoot in the depths of winter, picking up sacks of flour with their teeth --

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- Oh, yes, determination runs in the family.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: There is one thing I'd like you to tell me.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I'm trying to find things out myself -- that's the whole point.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: What made you think I'd be able to get you into the Castle?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: The cemetery is nearer the Castle than anywhere else -- wasn't it part of the Castle originally?  -- I always assumed there'd be a gate or something.  Isn't there?

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: In a manner of speaking.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: I was restoring some stones here in the upper section one day -- and I found this.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: An empty tomb?

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: A cenotaph -- a monument to someone whose remains ended up elsewhere. But look --

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: The Castle gates were blockaded in the time of the great plague -- it's an escape route.  Don't get stuck.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Not a chance.  I'm the thinnest person I know.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- You appreciate my writing.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Will you do me a favor then?

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: Another one?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: If I don't see you later -- go to my house and find my notebooks -- and destroy them.  All my manuscripts -- just burn them. Please.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: What an extraordinary request!

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: It's my last and final one.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: Then its authority is in doubt.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: A true friend would do it.

Speaker: bizzlebek
Dialogue: Not necessarily.  A wife would.

Speaker: gaunt man
Dialogue: You've killed him!  Like a dog!

Speaker: gaunt man
Dialogue: -- They won't like that.  Not a bit!

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I didn't --

Speaker: gaunt man
Dialogue: You'll incriminate the rest of us! Let me out too!

Speaker: horrible voices
Dialogue: Help us! -- release us!

Speaker: gaunt man
Dialogue: You're in the bowels now, my friend! You've thrown yourself in it now!

Speaker: gaunt man
Dialogue: Let me out -- I'm all right -- they haven't treated me yet!  We can go together!

Speaker: friendly clerk
Dialogue: Are you lost?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I'm, uh, looking for the Medical Records Section.

Speaker: friendly clerk
Dialogue: Oh, you're miles away.  From here you'll want to go left, left again, right, right again, left then right, right then left, and take the Blue Staircase.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: friendly clerk
Dialogue: -- I haven't seen you here before.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No ...

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: ... I'm new.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: I assume you're wondering ... what all this has been about.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Are you the Head of Medical Records?

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: -- Not something we encourage, mind you, but we like to know it exists.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: What it amounts to is simply this ...

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: A piece of paper was delivered to the wrong clerk.  It was essential he bring it back to us.  These complications have arisen because he had friends -- like you, among others -- friends unlikely to let a sleeping dog lie.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: ... A piece of paper ...

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: A mere slip.  Your friend Mr. Raban dealt only with claims that came in, another department being responsible for compensation that goes out -- this is correct?

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: Through a very unfortunate -- and I might add extremely rare -- mishap, a document intended for the one department was sent to the other.  And for the first time -- though your friend wasn't aware of it -- two and two could have been put together to make one.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: ... A piece of paper ...

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: You see, Kafka, in all cases relating to the factory at Orlac -- which is what this paper referred to -- the authority that puts in a request and the authority that grants it is, to all intents and purposes, the same authority.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: -- You seem amused.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: It only amuses me in that it gives me an insight into the ludicrous bungling that in some circumstances may decide the life of a human being.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: It's merely a matter of expediency.  It's imperative that my room to maneuver not be hindered by ... bureaucratic ramifications.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: -- If an obscure official up there in the distant mountains so far away from civilizing influences happens to meet with an unfortunate accident -- and should he tragically die in spite of the District Medical Officer's strenuous efforts to save him -- the firm wants to see the next of kin pacified and the disposition of the remains handled with the greatest possible ... efficiency.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: "Accident and Compensation" -- no one can accuse the firm of not supplying exactly what it promises.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: I believe we've exceeded his expectations.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: And I find you.  A body snatcher.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: Life is more than a Chinese puzzle, my friend.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: And I suppose Dr. Murnau didn't die in a cave-in.  You killed him to free the Position of Orlac Medical Officer for your own ends.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: Yes, well -- we're looking for a new village now.  If we stay too long at one source ... people become suspicious.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: But you're quite right that he didn't die in that cave-in. In fact, he didn't die at all. He was simply recalled -- by himself.  As well as being Head of Medical Records here and a Director of your firm -- I'm Dr. Murnau, of course.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: May I ask where your two warders are?

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Lying in the gutter where they belong.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: Pity.  They're an amusing pair, didn't you find?  Absolute innocents.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: I so rarely get the chance of showing my work to anybody -- anybody capable of appreciating it, that is.  You might say I'm a student of human reaction.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: The fact that it's live bodies you practice your trade on doesn't seem to matter to you.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: On the contrary, it matters a great deal.  We're engaged in immensely important research here.  I'm a revolutionary too, you know -- but a much more pragmatic one.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: -- I can't very well administer experimental treatments to corpses -- and if they become corpses, why, they have their uses too -- that's why speed is essential.  Living tissue, even if its owner has passed on, is our most valuable acquisition.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: We've tried transfusions on our ... volunteers.  Unfortunately, far from infusing superior characteristics it's tended to make them insane -- murderous even -- a condition we've had occasion to make use of.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: -- And the new patients they bring me aren't usually as dexterous as you've been in evading us.  Not perfect specimens by any means, but not the type of person who'll be missed either.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: What have you done with Gabriela Rossmann?

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: As a matter of fact you've caught us in a state of considerable excitement.  Our latest preparation we believe -- we pray -- is perfected. It should take years off her.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: And if not -- well, there are always what I call my caprices of vivisection.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: Actually, if it weren't for the aberrant dilemma posed by someone like yourself -- continually asking for out-of-date files -- I'd probably give up my revisionist policies altogether. I'm sure what we have to do is start instead at the very inception -- with the embryo -- from a single cell even.  The lure of the Golem -- the man-made man.  You appreciate that, I know.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: To corrupt the image of man and then offer redemption ... This is the dawn, Kafka.  A new man is being born here.  A more resilient man ... A superman.

Speaker: murnau
Dialogue: To a new world -- of Gods and monsters.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: Oskar!

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: Ludwig?

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: This is filed incorrectly!

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: Here too!  They're all in a dreadful muddle!

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Gabriela! -- you did get away.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: I knew you walked this way to work.  I wanted to find you before they did.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- I've just come from the Castle.  It's over.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Over?  It's only over when you can crawl to a clean little spot on earth where the sun sometimes shines and you can warm yourself a bit.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: Gabriela ...?

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Should I tell you why I joined our late lamented nihilists? Why I became a murderer? Because murder ... is bliss.  It's easier than you might think to absorb and assimilate Evil -- once you've adopted its procedure.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Have you ever watched a person deteriorate?  Day by day.  I don't mean in a spiritual sense.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Only two steps back?  Even the man they left to guard me retreated further than that.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I -- I found your jailer.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: This is the result of their elixir of youth.  They were to come and check on it during the night.  I contrived to miss the appointment.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: They're dead now.  We can get help.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: I know how they reward failure. If they saw this I'd be rotting in the quarries by the afternoon -- with all the others.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: There's a new potion -- he said it was perfected.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: I know there is.  And you're what I have to bargain with. For now you're the last one in their way.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: I told you, they're dead.  It's finished.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: Why should I believe a man who never believed me?  They're absolutely right, you know -- guilt should never be doubted. It's easier that way.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: I think you've just escaped for the moment.  Just as I did.  As Eduard did.  As they let us do. But only for the moment.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: No -- not this time.

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: I know better than you what people will say when they have to.  When they brought me in for questioning I informed on my friends the very first day.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- Listen to me --

Speaker: gabriela
Dialogue: I do.  Always.  You understand the world better than any of us, Kafka.  And what it's becoming.  I've always held you in the highest regard.

Speaker: kafka
Dialogue: -- Gabriela!

Speaker: kafka's voice
Dialogue: Dearest Father ...

Speaker: kafka's voice
Dialogue: You asked me recently why I maintain that I am afraid of you ...

Speaker: kafka's voice
Dialogue: Naturally things cannot in reality fit together the way the evidence does in my letter -- life is more than a Chinese puzzle.  But in my opinion something has been achieved which so closely approximates the truth that it might reassure us both a little and make our living and our dying easier.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: We could go back to the office. Explain ourselves to the Chief Clerk.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: They'd drive us away.  That Kafka's made things very hot for us.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: I understand he was wounded in the lung.

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: It doesn't matter.  It's too late for all of us.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: What's to become of us now?

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: Amerika.  That's the place to go.

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: Everyone in Amerika has a toaster in their building!

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: Then that's the place for us!

Speaker: ludwig
Dialogue: Amerika for us!

Speaker: oskar
Dialogue: Amerika!
